text: [Music]
I think of the nation magazine as the
anchor but I do think of the nation now
as a multimedia
Enterprise we have a website which
brings 2 million people to thenation.com
every month we are investing resources
we have uh bloggers who don't write for
the mag aine but who are writing for the
website
exclusively and I think that will be
important for the future because as I
said so many younger readers are reading
on the internet to me what's important
is that our ideas are out there and if
it's in the platform of the internet so
be it but the magazine then becomes a
vehicle also for the deeper essays which
we do the deeper investigative reporting
and it allows us for example with a
report we did a few weeks ago on mili
violence in New Orleans after the
Hurricane Katrina to then put primary
documents on the internet to deepen that
story we are doing radio and
podcasts and we are doing a weekly video
report whether it's one of the editors
talking about a story they've edited a
writer talking about how they've
investigated a
piece and events which we then video we
did an emergency town hall meeting
around the economic crisis at the end of
last year with Naomi Klein and and
William Grier we put that out there so
there's a multimedia sensibility but
always revolving around the core ideas
and Reporting mission of the
magazine one thing about the internet if
I might add is that it allows us also to
tap into the community of the nation
which is Broad and broadening and to we
have 38 discussion groups run by Nation
readers around this country and the
internet allows us to be in touch with
them telling them questions giving them
questions and ideas so it's a it's a
it's a way of connecting to a community
out there but the ad policy of the
nation interestingly was crafted uh
maybe 20 years ago by the former
director of the
ACLU we uh always air on the side of
free speech and in that context we are
very clear that we will publish ads we
don't agree with and we do so in the
service of publishing ideas the
companies might not agree with not that
we get big corporate ads the nation has
never been ad supported like K Nast or
some of the other major magazine
corporations but we have run over the
years ads which readers disagree with
ranging from the writer Lillian Helman
doing a black glamma fur ad many years
ago many years ago maybe 30 years ago
which prompted a lot of animal rights
activists to protest to ads Public
Public Service ads or public
promotional ads uh public affairs
ads which prompt readers to uh get very
involved in the politics of those ads
and send angry letters we run BP ads the
oil company we run cigarette ads and
those prompt angry letters and we
publish our ad policy every every few
months and it's online which is also
related to the question of how we run
ads on the web so that ad policy is
there for readers to
understand what we're doing
